docs.snippet: The debate over a ballot measure to ban gay marriage overshadowed other contests, including the presidential race and battles for a handful of Congressional districts.     The same-sex marriage ban passed with more than 52 percent of the vote....
docs.lead_paragraph: The debate over a ballot measure to ban gay marriage overshadowed other contests, including the presidential race and battles for a handful of Congressional districts. The same-sex marriage ban passed with more than 52 percent of the vote.

docs.snippet: Senator Gordon H. Smith, a two-term Republican, was in a nip-and-tuck race with Jeff Merkley, a Democrat who is the speaker of Oregon's state house. With  79 percent of the ballots counted, Mr. Smith had fallen behind Mr. Merkley by about 9,700 vo...
docs.lead_paragraph: Senator Gordon H. Smith, a two-term Republican, was in a nip-and-tuck race with Jeff Merkley, a Democrat who is the speaker of Oregon's state house. With 79 percent of the ballots counted, Mr. Smith had fallen behind Mr. Merkley by about 9,700 votes. Mr. Merkley has been counting on a statewide surge in voter registration among Democrats spurred by the campaign of Senator Barack Obama.
docs.abstract: Oregon Senate race between incumbent Republican Gordon H Smith and Democratic challenger Jeff Merkley remains undecided; Barack Obama wins state, 56-42 percent; tallies (S)

docs.snippet: A 1995 interview with Barack Obama finds the candidate focused on the same themes he is today....
docs.lead_paragraph: The blogger who calls himself (or herself) Existenz at Old Man McCain has unearthed a 1995 TV interview in which Barack Obama promotes his first book. "One can see that Barack Obama was already starting to think about issues of poverty and race in a political context," writes Existenz. "He mentions the 'race card,' Rev. Wright, his absent father, and his white grandmother -- all issues that would become oh so relevant here in 2008. It was also rather tragic to hear him mention his mother, since we know she would succumb to ovarian cancer later that year."
docs.abstract: A 1995 interview with Barack Obama finds the candidate focused on the same themes he is today.

docs.snippet: Intense analysis of Barack Obama's myth and reality has already begun....
docs.lead_paragraph: Barack Obama's pre-announcement of his 2008 presidential campaign took the form of a five-minute video biography. In his own video analysis, John Dickerson of Slate dissects the ad, pointing out how the announcement emphasizes the Illinois senator's biography, his popularity and his experience as an underdog and de-emphasizes his short Senate record. One black-and-white photo, showing the young Obama in a black turtleneck and leather jacket, Dickerson says, "appears to be the cover picture from his first jazz album."
docs.abstract: Intense analysis of Barack Obama's myth and reality has already begun.

docs.snippet: Richard J. Durbin, the Democratic Party whip in the Senate, scored an easy victory over four challengers. Exit polls show that he excelled in pretty much every category: he carried the black and white votes, and he beat his closest challenger, Ste...
docs.lead_paragraph: Richard J. Durbin, the Democratic Party whip in the Senate, scored an easy victory over four challengers. Exit polls show that he excelled in pretty much every category: he carried the black and white votes, and he beat his closest challenger, Steve Sauerberg, a Republican, among voters of every age and income, except those who make more than $200,000 a year. Mr. Sauerberg, a physician from the western suburbs of Chicago, ran a largely self-financed campaign around classic Republican tenets of smaller government, lower taxes and a strong military. Mr. Durbin, meanwhile, embraced the government-as-safety-net approach, favoring, for example, subsidized health coverage for the uninsured.
docs.abstract: Illinois Democrat Sen Richard Durbin wins re-election over four challengers; Democrats retain 12 of 18 Congressional seats; voters reject measure to re-write state's Constitution; Barack Obama wins state, 62-37 percent; tallies (S)
